item.title: The WebPageTest Waterfall Chart
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: The waterfall charts generated by WebPageTest are awash in information. If you find it all a bit too overwhelming, then I highly recommend How to read a WebPageTest waterfall chart.
item.content:encoded: The waterfall charts generated by WebPageTest are awash in information. If you find it all a bit too overwhelming, then I highly recommend How to read a WebPageTest waterfall chart.

item.title: WebPageTest and Lighthouse Terms
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: WebPageTest and Lighthouse have diverged a bit on terminology. I recently came across a Github WebPageTest issue where this came up and wanted to note it here for easy reference: Relative to lighthouse: WPT’s FirstInteractive === Lighthouse’s First CPU Idle WPT’s ConsistentlyInteractive === Lighthouse’s Time To Interactive
item.content:encoded:
WebPageTest and Lighthouse have diverged a bit on terminology. I recently came across a Github WebPageTest issue where this came up and wanted to note it here for easy reference:

Relative to lighthouse:

WPT’s FirstInteractive === Lighthouse’s First CPU Idle
WPT’s ConsistentlyInteractive === Lighthouse’s Time To Interactive

item.title: WebPageTest Agents and HTTPS
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: The EC2 AMI updates for WebPageTest include this commit. Prior to that test agents weren’t able to communicate with WPT servers that required HTTPS. In case you ran into this here is the simple work around. Let the test agent connect to WPT once ( via plain HTTP ), it will look for updates ( […]
item.content:encoded:
The EC2 AMI updates for WebPageTest include this commit. Prior to that test agents weren’t able to communicate with WPT servers that required HTTPS.

In case you ran into this here is the simple work around. Let the test agent connect to WPT once ( via plain HTTP ), it will look for updates ( and install them ), then switch to HTTPS. If that isn’t an option you can download just the Windows test agent code and update it manually ( not nearly as fun as the automatic update process ).

item.title: Authentication in WebPageTest Tests
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: If you have ever wondered how to run a WebPageTest test as an authenticated user on a site go read Using WebPageTest: Authentication from the 2015 edition of the Performance Calendar. It isn’t hard, but it also isn’t always obvious either.
item.content:encoded:
If you have ever wondered how to run a WebPageTest test as an authenticated user on a site go read Using WebPageTest: Authentication from the 2015 edition of the Performance Calendar.

It isn’t hard, but it also isn’t always obvious either.

item.title: Custom Chrome Network Throttling
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: If you’ve used Chrome Mobile Device Emulation then you’ve probably seen the network throttling option: Newer versions of Chrome allow you to create custom network throttling profiles: You can define a profile in terms of throughput ( kb/s ) and latency ( ms ): This is particularly useful if you want to use the same […]
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve used Chrome Mobile Device Emulation then you’ve probably seen the network throttling option:

Newer versions of Chrome allow you to create custom network throttling profiles:

You can define a profile in terms of throughput ( kb/s ) and latency ( ms ):

This is particularly useful if you want to use the same network throttling options in Chrome and WebPageTest:

item.title: Speed Index
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Speed Index is a great feature of WebPageTest. If you had to pick just one webperf metric to look at Speed Index would likely be it. The NCC Group has a really good walk through on how Speed Index is calculated. If you’ve had a hard time wrapping your head around Speed Index this article […]
item.content:encoded:
Speed Index is a great feature of WebPageTest. If you had to pick just one webperf metric to look at Speed Index would likely be it.

The NCC Group has a really good walk through on how Speed Index is calculated. If you’ve had a hard time wrapping your head around Speed Index this article is worth the time to read.

item.title: Speaking at OpenWest
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Next month I’ll be speaking at OpenWest on “Measuring Web Performance with WebPageTest”. The schedule has that listed for Thursday 7 May 2015 @ 2pm in Room PS 115.
item.content:encoded: Next month I’ll be speaking at OpenWest on “Measuring Web Performance with WebPageTest”. The schedule has that listed for Thursday 7 May 2015 @ 2pm in Room PS 115.

item.title: Behind the Scenes at WebPageTest
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Patrick Meenan gives an update on his Dulles, VA “data center” for webpagetest.org: As far as scaling the servers goes, I load up more VM’s than I expect to use, submit a whole lot of tests with all of the options enabled and watch the hypervisor’s utilization. I shut down VM’s until the CPU utilization […]
item.content:encoded:
Patrick Meenan gives an update on his Dulles, VA “data center” for webpagetest.org:

As far as scaling the servers goes, I load up more VM’s than I expect to use, submit a whole lot of tests with all of the options enabled and watch the hypervisor’s utilization. I shut down VM’s until the CPU utilization stays below 80% (one per CPU thread seems to be the sweet spot).

Moving up the rack we have the unraid NAS where the tests are archived for long-term storage (as of this post the array can hold 49TB of data with 18TB used for test results). I have a bunch of other things on the array so not all of that 30TB is free but I expect to be able to continue storing results indefinitely for the foreseeable future.

A big thank you to Patrick for all the work he has put into webpagetest.org. I’m particularly impressed with the effort being put into doing tests with real mobile devices.

item.title: WebPagetest.org API
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: If you’ve looked at front end performance you’ve probably come across webpagetest.org before. Did you know they have an API for running tests as well? Docs for the WebPagetest.org API are at https://sites.google.com/a/webpagetest.org/docs/advanced-features/webpagetest-restful-apis.
item.content:encoded: If you’ve looked at front end performance you’ve probably come across webpagetest.org before. Did you know they have an API for running tests as well? Docs for the WebPagetest.org API are at https://sites.google.com/a/webpagetest.org/docs/advanced-features/webpagetest-restful-apis.
